title: How to Wash Cotton Polyester

steps.headline: Read the care instructions printed on the tag.
steps.description: While most cotton-polyester blends will be perfectly fine in a washing machine and dryer, some articles of clothing may need to be hand-washed or line dried if they have printing on them or they’re particularly thin. Read the instructions printed on the tag thoroughly to determine if you need to do anything special for a piece of cotton-polyester clothing. This is a good tip for laundry in general. People tend to ignore the care instructions, but they are vitally important when it comes to not ruining that brand new sweater or shirt that you just bought!

steps.headline: Machine-wash your clothing unless the tag says otherwise.
steps.description: Cotton-polyester blends hold up better in the washing machine than almost every other textile. In fact, one of the main benefits of cotton-polyester clothing is that it is less prone to shrinking than 100% cotton and less likely to fade than 100% polyester. If there are no special instructions on the tag, toss it in with your standard laundry and wash it in the machine.Tip: Cotton-polyester blends may shrink slightly and there may be some minor fading, but blends should hold up better over time than 100% cotton or polyester. You can hand-wash a cotton-polyester blend if you’d like, but you won’t notice much wear and tear over time if you use the washing machine.

steps.headline: Use standard laundry detergent and add fabric softener if you want.
steps.description: Use the hash marks on your detergent’s cap to measure your detergent based on the size of your load. Pour your detergent directly into the machine like you normally do. You can use fabric softener if you’d like—it won’t have a major impact on cotton-polyester clothes. Despite popular belief, your clothes don’t get cleaner the more detergent you use. You only need to add a 1/3-1/2 cap of detergent to your laundry most of the time.

steps.headline: Choose your water temperature based on how dirty your clothes are.
steps.description: Warm water may slightly shrink cotton-polyester clothes, especially if they’re new, so only use warm water if your clothes are particularly dirty. Cold water won’t clean your clothes as thoroughly as warm water but it’s less likely to shrink your clothes, which makes it a good choice if they aren’t especially filthy. The washing machine is less likely to shrink your clothes than the dryer. If you’re really worried about shrinkage, air drying your clothes is the best way to avoid it.

steps.headline: Select the cycle setting based on the other clothes in your washer.
steps.description: Cotton-polyester clothing will hold up just fine in basically any wash cycle, so use the other clothing that you’re washing to determine your wash cycle. If you’re washing silk, linens, or other sensitive fabrics, use the delicate cycle setting. For thicker textiles, like denim, use the normal or standard setting. When in doubt, use the permanent press setting, which is usually a good middle ground for a variety of different fabrics. If you’re only washing cotton, polyester, or cotton-polyester clothes, use the standard setting if they’re really dirty. If they aren’t particularly filthy, use the permanent press setting.

steps.headline: Dry your clothes on a clothesline or hanger for best results.
steps.description: Air drying is the best way to ensure that your clothes don’t shrink or fade, since the friction and heat from the dryer can wear clothes out over time. After your wash cycle is finished, use clothespins to attach them to a clothing line outside. Alternatively, you can slide the clothes over a hanger and hang them in a well-ventilated area. Unless you have some bulky sheets or a thick cotton-polyester sweater, air drying should take 2-4 hours. You can use a drying rack instead of a hanger or clothesline if you prefer. Just be sure that your clothes aren’t touching one another while they dry or they may not dry properly.

steps.headline: Use the dryer if you don’t mind some slight wear and tear over time.
steps.description: Cotton-polyester clothing will do relatively well in the dryer compared to other fabrics. If you’re trying to get your clothes dry quickly, dry your cotton-polyester clothes in the dryer. If your cotton-polyester clothing is really colorful, it may fade over time with machine drying.

steps.headline: Choose the lowest heat setting necessary for your clothing.
steps.description: Use the lowest heat setting necessary based on the size of your load and the fabric being dried. For thinner fabrics and smaller loads, use the delicate or tumble-dry setting. If your load isn’t large and you don’t have any delicate fabrics, use the permanent press cycle. Only use the normal or regular setting if you’re drying a large load and have plenty of durable fabrics.Tip: The regular drying setting is kind of misleading. It usually uses the highest heat setting available unless you have a bulky sheets setting. If your load is exclusively comprised of cotton, polyester, or cotton-polyester clothes, use the permanent press setting unless you’re drying a bunch of clothes. In general, lower temperatures are better for your clothes than high temperatures.

steps.headline: Treat your stains before washing your cotton-polyester blends.
steps.description: Blot stains with a wet towel as soon as you notice them. Use a nontoxic stain remover to lift up any tough stains. For white clothes, you can use chlorine bleach to remove basically any stain. If you wash your cotton-polyester clothes without removing the stain first, you may end up setting the stain into the fabric permanently. White vinegar is a good natural option for stained cotton-polyester clothing as well.

steps.headline: Separate your laundry by color to keep clothes pristine.
steps.description: Washing your white clothing separately from your lightly-colored clothing and darks is the best way to ensure that whites stay bright and colored clothing doesn’t fade. Either separate your laundry before washing it, or keep separate laundry baskets for different colors to divide the loads ahead of time.

steps.headline: Turn colored clothing inside out before washing It.
steps.description: Colored clothing is more likely to fade or become discolored if the exterior of the fabric is rubbing against the sides of your washing machine or dryer. To keep colored clothing safe, turn it inside out before washing it.Tip: This is particularly important for brightly-colored cotton-polyester clothing, since polyester is already prone to fading over time.

steps.headline: Hang or fold your clothes as soon as they’re dry to prevent wrinkles.
steps.description: Letting your laundry sit in your dryer for too long will cause it to wrinkle. To keep your clothing looking as pristine as possible, fold it as soon as it’s done drying. For items that you want to store vertically, put them on hangers as soon as the dryer finishes running. This is less important for cotton-polyester clothing since it’s naturally more resistant to wrinkling. Still, it’s a good habit to get into if you want to keep laundry day efficient.

text: Washing Cotton Polyester Blends Read the care instructions printed on the tag. While most cotton-polyester blends will be perfectly fine in a washing machine and dryer, some articles of clothing may need to be hand-washed or line dried if they have printing on them or they’re particularly thin. Read the instructions printed on the tag thoroughly to determine if you need to do anything special for a piece of cotton-polyester clothing. This is a good tip for laundry in general. People tend to ignore the care instructions, but they are vitally important when it comes to not ruining that brand new sweater or shirt that you just bought! Machine-wash your clothing unless the tag says otherwise. Cotton-polyester blends hold up better in the washing machine than almost every other textile. In fact, one of the main benefits of cotton-polyester clothing is that it is less prone to shrinking than 100% cotton and less likely to fade than 100% polyester. If there are no special instructions on the tag, toss it in with your standard laundry and wash it in the machine.Tip: Cotton-polyester blends may shrink slightly and there may be some minor fading, but blends should hold up better over time than 100% cotton or polyester. You can hand-wash a cotton-polyester blend if you’d like, but you won’t notice much wear and tear over time if you use the washing machine. Use standard laundry detergent and add fabric softener if you want. Use the hash marks on your detergent’s cap to measure your detergent based on the size of your load. Pour your detergent directly into the machine like you normally do. You can use fabric softener if you’d like—it won’t have a major impact on cotton-polyester clothes. Despite popular belief, your clothes don’t get cleaner the more detergent you use. You only need to add a 1/3-1/2 cap of detergent to your laundry most of the time. The washing machine is less likely to shrink your clothes than the dryer. If you’re really worried about shrinkage, air drying your clothes is the best way to avoid it. Select the cycle setting based on the other clothes in your washer. Cotton-polyester clothing will hold up just fine in basically any wash cycle, so use the other clothing that you’re washing to determine your wash cycle. If you’re washing silk, linens, or other sensitive fabrics, use the delicate cycle setting. For thicker textiles, like denim, use the normal or standard setting. If you’re only washing cotton, polyester, or cotton-polyester clothes, use the standard setting if they’re really dirty. If they aren’t particularly filthy, use the permanent press setting. Drying Your Clothing Dry your clothes on a clothesline or hanger for best results. Air drying is the best way to ensure that your clothes don’t shrink or fade, since the friction and heat from the dryer can wear clothes out over time. After your wash cycle is finished, use clothespins to attach them to a clothing line outside. Alternatively, you can slide the clothes over a hanger and hang them in a well-ventilated area. Unless you have some bulky sheets or a thick cotton-polyester sweater, air drying should take 2-4 hours. You can use a drying rack instead of a hanger or clothesline if you prefer. Just be sure that your clothes aren’t touching one another while they dry or they may not dry properly. Use the dryer if you don’t mind some slight wear and tear over time. Cotton-polyester clothing will do relatively well in the dryer compared to other fabrics. If you’re trying to get your clothes dry quickly, dry your cotton-polyester clothes in the dryer. If your cotton-polyester clothing is really colorful, it may fade over time with machine drying. Choose the lowest heat setting necessary for your clothing. Use the lowest heat setting necessary based on the size of your load and the fabric being dried. For thinner fabrics and smaller loads, use the delicate or tumble-dry setting. If your load isn’t large and you don’t have any delicate fabrics, use the permanent press cycle. Only use the normal or regular setting if you’re drying a large load and have plenty of durable fabrics.Tip: The regular drying setting is kind of misleading. It usually uses the highest heat setting available unless you have a bulky sheets setting. If your load is exclusively comprised of cotton, polyester, or cotton-polyester clothes, use the permanent press setting unless you’re drying a bunch of clothes. In general, lower temperatures are better for your clothes than high temperatures. Cleaning Cotton-Polyester Blends Efficiently Treat your stains before washing your cotton-polyester blends. Blot stains with a wet towel as soon as you notice them. Use a nontoxic stain remover to lift up any tough stains. For white clothes, you can use chlorine bleach to remove basically any stain. White vinegar is a good natural option for stained cotton-polyester clothing as well. Separate your laundry by color to keep clothes pristine. Either separate your laundry before washing it, or keep separate laundry baskets for different colors to divide the loads ahead of time. Turn colored clothing inside out before washing It. Colored clothing is more likely to fade or become discolored if the exterior of the fabric is rubbing against the sides of your washing machine or dryer. To keep colored clothing safe, turn it inside out before washing it.Tip: This is particularly important for brightly-colored cotton-polyester clothing, since polyester is already prone to fading over time. Hang or fold your clothes as soon as they’re dry to prevent wrinkles. Letting your laundry sit in your dryer for too long will cause it to wrinkle. To keep your clothing looking as pristine as possible, fold it as soon as it’s done drying. For items that you want to store vertically, put them on hangers as soon as the dryer finishes running. This is less important for cotton-polyester clothing since it’s naturally more resistant to wrinkling. Still, it’s a good habit to get into if you want to keep laundry day efficient.
